misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation for Assigned Task
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program for calculating the distance between two points, which does not address the required task of implementing a Grade Calculator. All requirements regarding input, grading logic, and output were ignored.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code, which calculates the distance between two points, fulfills the requirements for the Grade Calculator problem (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be specifically designed to read a single numeric grade and apply conditional logic to determine and print the corresponding letter grade, as detailed in the Q3 problem statement.
symptoms: Program calculates distance, not grade.
Requires four inputs (coordinates) instead of one (grade).
Output format is incorrect for the assignment.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly map the program code to the specific requirements of the assigned problem (Q3). This is likely due to submitting the wrong file or failure to read the prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always verify that your implemented logic directly addresses every requirement listed in the problem description, including input structure, processing steps, and output format. Start by only taking the required input (a single grade).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is explicitly solving a different, unrelated geometry problem (Distance Between Points), making the failure to implement the required Grade Calculator task unequivocal.

evidence.note: The entire program, including input collection and calculation, is dedicated to solving the distance problem, not the grade calculator problem.

misconceptions.name: Problem misunderstanding - solving wrong assignment
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete solution to a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This suggests either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or copying code from a different exercise without reading the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code solves the grade calculator problem, or failed to read the actual assignment before writing code.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and converting it to a letter grade using conditional logic. The student should have written code to read one integer/double, then use if-else statements to determine and output the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program reads four coordinate values instead of one grade
Program calculates and outputs a distance instead of a letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' which has nothing to do with grades
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
No letter grade output (A, B, C, D, F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either did not read the problem statement carefully, copy-pasted code from a different exercise without adaptation, or submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over: (1) Read the problem statement carefully. (2) Read one grade value from user. (3) Use if-else if statements to check ranges: if (grade >= 90) for A, else if (grade >= 80) for B, etc. (4) Output the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is objectively solving a completely different problem. The mismatch between the assignment (grade calculator) and the submission (distance calculator) is unambiguous.

evidence.note: This entire program solves a distance calculation problem, not the grade calculator assignment. It reads four coordinate values and outputs a distance, rather than reading one grade and outputting a letter grade.
Prompts for coordinate input (x1, y1) instead of a numeric grade as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem than the specification
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as I write a correct Java program (in this case, computing the distance between two points), it is acceptable for this question, even if it does not follow the described grade-calculator requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each problem, the program must implement exactly what the specification describes. In this question, the program should read a single numeric grade (0–100), use conditional statements to check which numeric range it falls into (A/B/C/D/F), and then print the corresponding letter grade (e.g., "Letter grade: B"). Any other program, even if it compiles and runs correctly, does not answer this question.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates ("Enter x1 and y1", "Enter x2 and y2") instead of a single grade.
Program never reads a single numeric grade value representing 0–100.
Program never uses any conditional (if/else) logic to classify ranges.
Output describes distance between points instead of a letter grade.
None of the rubric-required behaviors (grade ranges, letter outputs) appear in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions (e.g., reusing code from a distance-between-points exercise) or not carefully reading the current problem statement. The student may be focusing on producing any working Java program rather than mapping the given specification to the required logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite the program so that it:
1) Prompts for and reads a single numeric grade (0–100) using Scanner.
2) Uses if/else-if/else statements to check whether the grade is in 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, or below 60.
3) Prints the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) in the required format, e.g., "Letter grade: B".
Do not reuse code from other problems unless it actually solves this specification.
related_concepts: Basic console input and output with Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is a standard solution for a distance-between-points task and contains none of the elements requested in the grade-calculator problem, strongly suggesting the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: All logic is for computing distance between two points; there is no reading of a grade, no conditional ranges, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Solved Incorrect Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade calculator logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the required task was calculating the distance between points, or they accidentally submitted a solution to a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct task was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code implements geometry calculation instead of grade classification.
Input prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
Output is 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment requirements, submitting the wrong file, or confusing it with a previous assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment prompt for Q3. Delete all geometry-related code and replace it with steps to read a single grade input and apply the required conditional logic (if-else structure) based on the grading scale.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the requested problem (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The entire program calculates point distance, which is not the assigned task (Grade Calculator).

misconceptions.name: Problem Task Misalignment
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for an entirely different problem (distance calculation between two points). The submission does not address any of the requirements for the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance-between-points problem rather than a grade-calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly asks for a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade value
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of converting grades to letters
Output prints distance value instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade-to-letter mapping
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either copy-pasted code from a different assignment, misread the problem statement, or submitted the wrong file entirely. This suggests insufficient care in verifying problem requirements before submission.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. Create a new program that reads a single grade value (0-100), uses if-else statements to check ranges (90+ for A, 80-89 for B, 70-79 for C, 60-69 for D, below 60 for F), and outputs the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence. The submitted code is for a completely different problem. The class name, variable names, input prompts, calculations, and output all correspond to a distance-calculation program, not a grade-conversion program.

evidence.note: Reads coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade (0-100).
Calculates Euclidean distance formula instead of comparing grade to ranges.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + DISTANCE);
evidence.note: Outputs distance calculation instead of letter grade.
